name: Egilsstaðir - Capital of East Iceland
description: Egilsstaðir is the undisputed capital of East Iceland and the largest settlement in the Eastern Region, serving as the main center of services, transportation, and administration for this remote and beautiful part of the country. With a population of approximately 2,632 inhabitants as of 2024, this young town (founded in 1944) has grown into a vital hub that provides all essential services for travelers and residents alike, including supermarkets, hotels, restaurants, tour operators, an information center, souvenir shops, a regional hospital, a college, and Iceland's easternmost airport with regular domestic flights and increasing international connections. Located on the banks of the scenic Lagarfljót River in the wide Fljótsdalshérað valley, Egilsstaðir occupies a strategic position surrounded by some of East Iceland's most spectacular natural attractions, making it an ideal base for exploring the region. The town sits near two of Iceland's little-known gems: Hallormsstaðaskógur, Iceland's largest forest (a rarity in this largely treeless nation) where hiking trails wind through birch and conifer woodlands that feel almost magical in Icelandic context; and the mysterious Lagarfljót lake, Iceland's third-largest lake by volume, whose deep, dark waters are said to harbor the Lagarfljótsormurinn—a serpent-like monster similar to the Loch Ness Monster that has been "sighted" by locals for centuries and remains a beloved part of East Icelandic folklore. Just a short drive from town, visitors can explore the dramatic Hengifoss waterfall, Iceland's third-highest at 128 meters, which cascades down a cliff face striped with red clay layers and black basalt, creating a stunning geological timeline visible from the hiking trail; and nearby Litlanesfoss, framed by spectacular hexagonal basalt columns reminiscent of Svartifoss. For those seeking geothermal relaxation, the Laugarvellir hot spring offers an amazing bathing experience where natural hot water cascades as a waterfall directly into a soaking pool—a unique combination of geothermal spa and natural waterfall. The East Iceland Heritage Museum in Egilsstaðir presents comprehensive exhibitions about the region's history, culture, and traditions, with particular focus on the harsh realities of rural life, turf house architecture, and the resilience of East Icelandic communities. The nearby Skriðuklaustur cultural center occupies the former home of famous Icelandic author Gunnar Gunnarsson and now serves as a museum, art gallery, and venue for cultural events surrounded by beautiful gardens. Egilsstaðir is also the only place in Iceland where wild reindeer can be found—these majestic animals were imported from Norway in the late 18th century and now roam the highlands and mountains of East Iceland, occasionally spotted near roads during autumn migrations.
